string-array.name: destinationDescriptionLong
string-array.item: Landmark 17th-century Mughal fortress built in towering red sandstone, now a complex of museums.
73m tapering tower built in 1193 by Qutab-ud-din Aibak after defeat of Delhi\'s last Hindu kingdom.
Imposing Arc de Triomphe-style gate commemorating the Indian soldiers killed in the First World War.
17th-century, red sandstone Mughal-style mosque with a 25,000 capacity & 40m high minarets.
Opulent red-sandstone tomb of Mughal Emperor Humayun, built in 1572 & surrounded by formal gardens.
Religious site also known as the Lotus Temple, opened in 1986 and open to those of all religions.
Over 11,000 artisans worked on this lavishly decorated Hindu temple complex inaugurated in 2005.
Official residence plus Mughal and herbal gardens of the President of India, with visits by request.
13 architectural astronomy instruments built in 1724 at the orders of Mughal emperor Muhammad Shah.
This large Hindu temple covers 7.5 acres & features numerous shrines, fountains & a garden.

string-array.name: food_description
string-array.item: Start off with one of the oldest eateries in Delhi. This 100-year-old shop is known for serving giant, hot and juicy Jalebis.
A plate of Dahi Bhalla at Natraj is a ritual for people who visit Chandni Chowk regularly.
If Choley Bhature and lassi is food anaesthesia, then this place will induce food coma!
For years, people have been queueing up in front of Alkauser every evening, hoping their kebabs are not sold out.
Jama Masjid is a paradise for a food lovers, and this iconic place is right at the entrance of this paradise.
The true place for Mughlai food.
You will fall in love at first bite!
The man behind the kadhai can pick up fried pakoras from the hot oil with bare hands. It happens only in Delhi!
You won\’t be able to finish a plate by yourself.
If you\'re not drooling already, this will surely make you drool!

string-array.name: restaurant_where
string-array.item: Where: 795, Dariba Kalan Road, Dariba Corner, Opposite to Central Baptist Church, Chandni chowk
Where: 1396, Main Road Near Central Bank, Opposite, Paranthe Wali Gali, Kucha Mahajani, Chandni Chowk
Where: 30, Vasant Place Market, Near Malai Temple, R K Puram, New Delhi
Where: No.8, Jama Masjid Matia Mahal Road, Matia Mahal
Where: Jama Masjid, Gali Kababian, Old Delhi
Where: 29, Defence Colony Market, Defence Colony, New Delhi
Where: 2298, Gurudwara Road Chowk, Karol Bagh, New Delhi
Where: 651/52, Church Mission Road, Fatehpuri, Chandni Chowk

string-array.name: restaurant_timing
string-array.item: Timings: 12 pm to 4 pm, 7 pm to 11 pm (7 pm to 11 pm on Tuesday)

string-array.name: shopDescriptionLong
string-array.item: This historic market has existed for hundreds of years — since merchants from China and Europe first arrived and began to sell their wares in India. A real treasure trove for shoppers, the market is helpfully divided into bazaars with different areas of specialization: fabrics in Katra Neel, silver in Dariba Kalan, needlework in Kinari Bazaar, and electronics in Bhagirath Palace.

While not for the faint-hearted, this market is a must for backpackers, as some of the best bargain shopping in New Delhi can be done here. Paharganj market deals in wholesale and exports to foreign countries, making it the perfect place to browse for inexpensive clothing, shoes, jewelry, books, music, textiles, handicrafts, hookah pipes, incense, and anything else on your souvenir list.

The \'Piazza\' of Delhi, Connaught Place is an impressive example of original colonial architecture — and also a massive shopping area! Though some say it\'s gone a little downhill in recent years, the flea market here is still a reliable spot for snatching-up great deals on everything from saris and silver to perfumes and pashmina shawls. Keep your eyes open, as there\'s a bargain to be had on literally every corner!
Popular and lively, Janpath Market sells authentic goods from both India and Tibet, making it a favorite for hippie clothing, shoes, leather-work and cheap traditional artifacts.

Khan Market offers not only a few great Indian-branded clothing outlets, but also several excellent bookshops and newsstands. You can also get your suit flawlessly tailored within a week, buy Ayurvedic herbs and cosmetics, or relax in one of the many good cafes, restaurants, and lounges situated here.

If you are a savvy designer-clothes shopper who\'d relish the chance to browse brand-name accessories and shoes — reduced due to surplus or small manufacturing defects — then Sarojini Nagar Market is the place for you! There\'s also a sweet market (Babu Market) and vegetable market (Subzi Mundi) for when your energy levels need a helping hand.

The regular tourist may visit Dilli Haat for its traditional village atmosphere — complete with thatch-roofed cottages — but the \'shopping tourist\' comes for its array of Indian handicrafts and artifacts. Another distinctive feature is that the artists sell their own goods themselves — meaning your money does not go through any middlemen.

One of the oldest markets in India, Lajpat Nagar provides an interesting picture of modern Indian shopping culture. Its roadside stalls and showrooms are packed with local Indian shoppers buying clothing, shoes, bags, bangles, and even home furnishings. The market\'s food stalls offer delicious snacks and drinks — as well as good people-watching.

Though a little spread-out and chaotic, South Extension Market is the place to be if you are looking for up-market, high-street shopping in Delhi. The market is divided into two parts: South Extension I is the place to head to for brand-name clothing, fashion jewelry, music and sweets, whereas South Extension II has a lounge and several other good-quality restaurants.
